Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Use segmented resumable package uploads" (#8915) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Today NuGet package uploads are "one shot" - either the upload completely succeeds or fails. A network hiccup causes the whole upload to restart even if the upload was 99% complete. This is particularly problematic as:

* nuget.org's upload services are in North America. Customers in locations like China experience high amounts of slow or failed requires. _‚ö† TODO: Quantify this with data_
* NuGet packages can be up to 250mb. Large uploads have a higher probability of failure. _‚ö† TODO: Quantify this with data_

### The Elevator Pitch

See: http://highscalability.com/blog/2016/4/20/how-twitter-handles-3000-images-per-second.html

NuGet could divide packages into segments and append each segment to the upload.

For example, imagine I want to upload a 1mb package. Here's what this could look like using segmented resumable uploads:

1. I split my package into four segments of 256KB.
2. I upload the first segment to nuget.org and receive an upload ID `x`
3. I append the second segment to nuget.org using upload ID `x` 
4. I append the third segment to nuget.org using upload ID `x`
5. I attempt to append the fourth segment to nuget.org using upload ID `x`. Let's say this fails
6. I retry and append the fourth segment to nuget.org using upload ID `x`. This completes my upload

This may be useful to prevent denial of service attacks.

### Additional Context and Details

TODO:

* [ ] Determine need using data
* [ ] Research how other services implement segmented resumable uploads

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Some problems with README Markdown rendering" (#8913) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

I've uploaded a README file together with my NuGet package (https://www.nuget.org/packages/PandocFilters/) and the rendered Markdown is a little less than ideal:
1. Language codes for code blocks are ignored; no syntax highlighting.
2. There is no whitespace between cells in the rendered table.
3. No support for superscript (`<sup>...</sup>`).

### Repro Steps

Upload a README file for a NuGet package containing misrendered Markdown.

### Expected Behavior

Syntax highlighting for code blocks should render properly.

There should be some whitespace between table cells.

A limited set of HTML elements should be supported, `sup` in my case.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: [Pack] No restore info shows in the CLI when running command ‚Äúdotnet pack --no-dependencies‚Äù" (#11430) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

Dotnet SDK Version: 6.0.200-preview.21573.3

### Worked before?

Worked on Dotnet SDK Version: 5.0.200-preview.21077.7

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context
#### Details about the problem
VS Version: Main\32002.62
NuGet Version: Dev\6.1.0.68
OS Version: Windows-11-Enterprise-21H2

#### Repro steps
1. Create a solution with two C# ClassLibrary (.NET 6.0) projects.
2. Make the project1 reference project2.
3. Open CLI and go to the path of above solution. 
4. Run the command ‚Äúdotnet pack --no-dependencies‚Äù.

#### Expected
There should be only one restore info for the project1 (like ‚ÄúRestored ‚Ä¶\project1.csproj‚Äù) in the CLI as the [dotnet pack doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-pack?tabs=netcore2x) said as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/144576288-05eaf5af-6a0c-45d0-8589-cee8ca699ebd.png)
Worked on Dotnet SDK Version: 5.0.200-preview.21077.7 as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/144578096-dee6cfd5-8e08-41e5-a096-39896ef99dbf.png)

#### Actual
No restore info shows in the CLI as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/144576551-8f50c3a2-6e0f-41b5-99ed-ad1b69e14b6e.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Stop using PublicAPIAnalyzer on projects that are MSBuild tasks" (#11470) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`NuGet.Build.Tasks` and `NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack` are projects that pack into packages that provide NuGet's MSBuild target functionality. `NuGet.Build.Tasks.Console` is a console app, used by `NuGet.Build.Tasks`, to provide restore using a different MSBuild API. None of these are libraries intended for customers to use as APIs in their own projects, and for at least one of these projects, when included with a `PackageReference`, the assemblies are not referenced by defaults, so customers must intentionally go out of their way to try to invoke it as an API.

In any case, we won't provide any API or ABI compatibility guarantees for the assemblies, only the MSBuild target experience. Hence we don't need the public API analyzer.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Packing a multi-target project fails to find the configured readme file" (#11467) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

6.0.101

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create a blank C# project.
2. Create a readme.md file in the project.
3. Configure this readme file to be included in the package by right click project > Properties > Package > General > README, browse to said readme.md. Build and pack project once to verify that it packs successfully at this step.
4. Open the project's .csproj file, find `TargetFramework` tag and change it to `TargetFrameworks`. Note: adding additional target framework(s) in this tag is not necessary.
5. Build and pack project again to see the error.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Error code: NU5039
The readme file 'readme.md' does not exist in the package.
A demonstrative video of reproducing this bug can also be found here: https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/598678594750775301/924001576643878923/2021-12-25_00-57-31.mp4
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PackageReference ungracefully handles duplicate Runtime Identifiers in csproj PackageReference " (#9290) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Specifically see: 

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/9ba90610a465d3c73921ba88b0e338b71a17fc72/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio/Projects/VsProjectAdapter.cs#L310-L313

Repro:
Create a csproj.dll PR project.
Manually edit the project and set:

```xml
<RuntimeIdentifier>win</RuntimeIdentifier>
<RuntimeIdentifiers>win</RuntimeIdentifiers>
```

And see an exception:
```cs
 System.ArgumentException: An item with the same key has already been added.
```

Validate the same experience with SDK based projects.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Introduce a warning for null/empty version range (new or reuse NU1604)" (#9767) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NU1604 currently complains that a project has a dependency without an inclusive lower bound.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu1604

Now, often times this is true, but most frequently, the problem is that someone was playing with MSBuild and the variable that contains the version is now empty.  

The message can reflect that. 

We could introduce a new warning, but maybe there's no need for that.
